Precipitation of silver nanoparticles in silicate glasses via Nd:YAG nanosecond laser and its characterization
A.A. Menazeaa,b,⁎, A.M. Abdelghanyb,c, W.H. Osmand, N.A. Hakeemb, F.H. Abd El-Kaderd
a Laser Technology Unit, Physics Division, National Research Center, 33 ElBehouth St., Dokki, 12311 Giza, Egypt b Spectroscopy Department, Physics Division, National Research Center, 33 ElBehouth St., Dokki, 12311 Giza, Egypt c Basic Science Department, Horus University, International Coastal Rd, New Damietta, Kafr Saad, Damietta, Egypt d Physics Department, Faculty of Science, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Silicate glasses Nd:YAG AgNPs XRD FT-IR;UV-Vis. HRTEM
A B S T R A C T
This work presents a new route to synthesis nanomaterials for nonlinear optical devices, Nd:YAG laser irradiation is considered as recent technique for precipitation of nanoparticles in glassy matrix. Precipitation of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) in silicate glasses is achieved by Nd:YAG nanosecond laser irradiation to soda lime silicate glasses doped with silver nitrate (AgNO3) using melt annealing technique. The influences of different concentrations of AgNO3 on the optical and the structural characterization of the precipitated glasses were investigated using; XRD, FT-IR, UV–Vis, and HRTEM. An obvious change in color was observed inside the silicate glasses regions after laser irradiation, which was attributed to the growth of silver nanoparticles in the glass.XRD patterns indicate the presence of sharp diffraction peaks of AgNPs after laser irradiation due to precipitated AgNPs in silicate glasses. FT-IR spectra of the precipitated samples show a little change in intensity for the sample before and after the laser irradiation combined with the identification of a new band that approves the precipitated AgNPs. The optical absorption spectra confirm the formation of the precipitated AgNPs inside the silicate glasses by appearance of Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) and the intensity of the absorption peak increases with an increase of the silver nitrate concentration. TEM micrographs confirm the precipitation of silver within the samples after laser irradiation.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Metallic nanoparticles have been intensively studied in many fields due to their amazing physical and chemical properties which are extremely different from the bulk phase. The nanomaterials have several applications such as; optical waveguides, optical switches, memory devices, gas sensors, surfaces of heat exchangers, and heterogeneous catalysts [1,2].
Silver nanoparticles attracted a great attention in using for various applications in medical tools, appliances, and healthcare products due to their electrical, biochemical, optical, magnetic and catalytic properties [3–5]. Therefore, the researchers have focused on studying the physical, chemical, electrical, and optical properties of silver nanoparticles [6–8].
Glasses are considered as amorphous or non-periodic solid materials which possess high chemical durability, high transparent, and excellent electrical and thermal properties. Also they have a several applications in different areas such as; tableware, optoelectronics, and window
panes. Glasses containing nanomaterial such as; gold, silver, and copper nanoparticles are favorable materials for technological applications in optics, optoelectronics devices, photonic, and three-dimensional multicolored photos inside transparent materials [9].
Such heterogeneous materials, being consist of metallic nano-clusters in amorphous matrices, are fabricated by a several of methods. The most successful methods are low energy ion-beam mixing [10], sol–gel [11], direct metal ion implantation [12], and annealing of ion exchanged glasses in hydrogen atmosphere or evaporation condensation [13,14].Various microstructures characterization is created when the pulses of laser are focused into glasses due to multiphoton processes [15].
In recent years, a hard effort has been focused to processing a route for the preparation of such nanocomposite which uses nanosecond pulses laser irradiation for precipitation of silver nanoparticles in the silicate glasses and is advanced and received a great attention as a new technique [16,17].

In particular, silicate glasses containing AgNPs are considered as an excellent choice for different nonlinear optical devices related to Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) that mainly depends on shape and size of metallic NPs in addition to that of an embedding medium [18,19].
A number of experimental works with pulsed Nd:YAG laser irradiation has a broad applications which concern optical waveguides, metal polymer nanostructures and photochromic glasses and which all are induced in the precipitation process in soda lime glasses because of its nonlinear response characteristics [15].
The present work aims to study the precipitation and the generation of Silver nanoparticles inside the bulk of silicate glasses by Nd:YAG nanosecond laser irradiation at its fundamental wavelength 1064 nm to soda lime silicate glass doped by silver nitrate (AgNO3) using melt annealing technique. We have investigated the structural and optical characterizations of the precipitated glasses samples at different concentration of AgNO3 by XRD, FT-IR, and UV–Vis techniques.

sections.heading: 2.1. Fabrications of silicate glass samples
sections.text: Soda lime silicate glasses doped by AgNO3 were successfully prepared via conventional melt annealing technique. The glass compositions were depicted in Table 1. All materials were supplied by Sigma Aldrich. Accurately weighed amounts of composition were mixed well together in an gate mortar then melted in platinum crucibles under the normal atmospheric condition at about 1450 °C for one hour. The crucibles were rotated several times every 15min during melting process to ensure complete mixing, bubbles free, and homogeneity. Then the melts were quenched into transparent and colorless glass by pouring them onto a preheated stainless steel mold of required dimensions (20mm×10mm×2mm) and the samples were transferred immediately to an annealing muffle furnace regulated at 450 °C. After 30min, the muffle was turned off and left to cool gradually to room temperature by a rate of 20 °C/h to remove any thermal stresses and to obtain samples of required dimensions and were polished for spectral measurements.

sections.heading: 2.2. Precipitation of Ag nanoparticles by laser irradiation
sections.text: The prepared glass samples were irradiated by the fundamental harmonic (λ=1064 nm) Nd:YAG nanosecond laser. The laser was incident directly to the surface of glass sample by using 100mm focal length quartz convex lens. The distance between the surface of glass sample and the lens was shorter than the focal length to release the laser spot on it. The spot diameter of the laser beam was 3.3mm. The distance between the laser source and the target glass sample was 25 cm, approximately. The glass sample was placed on low speed motorized XY scanning stage to insure the precipitation of silver nanoparticles in the majority of the glass surface. All silicate glass samples were irradiated to the same laser parameters; 5min irradiation time, 5W powers, 8 ns pulse duration and 10 Hz repetition rate.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization techniques
sections.text: The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the precipitated silicate glasses was carried out using PANalytical XPert PRO XRD system occupied with copper Kα radiation (λ=1.540 Å) with a tube operating voltage of about 30 kV and within Bragg angle (2θ) (5°-80°). Fourier transform infrared measurements were carried out with Nicolet is 10 single beam spectrometer via KBr powder route that collect 32 scans with resolution 2 cm−1. 2 mg spectroscopic grade KBr mixed with 1mg sample for quantitative calculations in the absorbance mode at spectral range 4000–400 cm−1. The spectrum was recorded immediately after preparation in triplicate and average readings were calculated. UV–Vis. optical absorption spectra of highly polished glassy samples of 2mm thickness were recorded at room temperature using JASCO Corp, V570, Rel. 60 double beam spectrometer within the range 200–1000 nm. High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM) was performed by (JEOLJEM- 2100F, Japan) electron microscope with accelerating voltage of 200 kV.

sections.heading: 3.1. The X-ray diffraction (XRD)
sections.text:
XRD scans for powdered samples of the prepared soda lime silicate glass doped by different concentrations (G0 to G5) of silver nitrate without any laser radiation (Fig. 1) and the silicate glasses precipitated by silver nanoparticles by nanosecond laser irradiation within Bragg angles from 5 to 80°at room temperature are depicted in Fig. 2.
XRD patterns in Fig. 1 for all the studied silicate glasses samples doped by silver nitrate without any laser radiation, exhibit few diffused scattering peaks with the absence of any sharp peak indicating the noncrystallinity/amorphous nature of the structural ordering of the glassy samples. These amorphous nature features are characterized by two halos centered at 2θ=27° and 44° and the appearance of these broad peaks may be attributed to the residual ordered nature of silicate glasses.
XRD patterns in Fig. 2 of the silicate glasses doped by silver nitrate at different concentration (G1, G3, G5) after nanosecond laser irradiation show sharp peak around 2θ≈ 27° for (G1: x= 0.1) and for (G3: x= 0.5 and G5: x= 1.0), the two halos centered at 2θ=27° and 44° are decreasing by increasing the concentration of silver nitrate (x).it was also known that in case of crystallite formation or clusterization a
peak FWHM and intensity can govern the size and distribution of nanostructure.
The disappearance of the peaks in AgNPs may be attributed to weak reflections from ordered structure and because of the low loading of AgNPs in silicate glasses matrix, also, and/or the small size of AgNPs. Moreover, it can be suggested that the complexation between AgNPs and silicate glass matrix takes places in the amorphous region.

sections.heading: 3.2. Fourier transform infrared analysis (FT-IR)
sections.text:
Infrared absorption spectra of the undoped silicate glass in combination with the other samples that contain different content of silver nitrate are illustrated in Fig. 3. It is observed that six bands are identified at 3437 cm−1, 1623 cm−1, 1458 cm−1,998 cm−1,875 cm−1, and 691 cm−1. Consequently the IR spectra of alkali silicate glasses can be assigned to the following origins [20]:
1. Bands at 400–505 and 600 cm−1, are correlated with Si-O-Si and O-
Si-O bending modes. 2. Bands around 770–820 cm−1, are attributed to of Si-O-Si Symmetric
stretching of bridging oxygen between tetrahedra. 3. Bands around 970–1095 cm−1, are related to Si-O-Si anti-symmetric
stretching of bridging oxygen within the tetrahedra. 4. Bands at 1460 cm−1, is related to carbonate groups. 5. Band at 1640 cm−1, can be related to molecular water or hydroxyl
related band. 6. Bands around 2800–2980 cm−1, are attributed to asymmetric and
symmetric stretching modes of interstitial H2O molecules. 7. Bands around 3400–3500 cm−1, are due to molecular water. 8. Bands around 3600–3950 cm−1, are attributed to different
stretching modes of silanol Si (OH) groups.
The published IR spectra of crystalline and silicate glasses agreed with the same introduced assignments. SiO4 tetrahedron is considered as the basic building unit in silicate glasses. In silicate glasses, the absorption bandat 1100 cm−1isrelated to the vibration Si-O-Si bond stretching type which is identified at 1065 cm−1 in crystalline quartz shape and at 1085 cm−1 band in crystallinecristobalite.
As each alkali oxideis added to SiO2such as Na2O to the silicate glasses, each of the oxygen atoms and the metal cationare inserted in the structure. The non-bridging oxygen ions are introduced in the space that generated from the broken tetrahedral (Si-O-Si) linkages, the metal ions are assumed to occupy the interstitial position in the structure and enhance the neutrality to the negative charges in the non-bridging oxygens [21].
FT-IR spectra after laser irradiation was found to be completely changed especially in the finger print region in the spectral range changed 1750–1500 cm−1 due to the rearrangement of silver ion in the glassy matrices as shown in Fig. 4.

sections.heading: 3.3. Ultraviolet-visible absorption measurements (UV-Vis)
sections.text:
UV/Visible optical absorption spectra before irradiation process reveal nearly the same behavior which consists of a small peak originally located in the region 200–250 nm depending on composition of the glass and was previously attributed by different authors [22,23] to different impurities present in the glass matrices, often iron even in a ppm level as shown in Fig. 5.
Fig. 5 confirms that the strong UV absorption spectra are fixed in irradiated samples small consisting of kinks at 220 and 250 nm. The
undoped silicate glasses offered a broad UV spectrum revealing two bands at 230 and 275 nm. These strong UV bands that obtained from Fig. 5 were attributed to the existence of iron traces impurities, which were induced inside the raw chemicals that related to the glasses preparation. Therefore, it was obtained the UV absorption spectra that founded in the studied silicate glasses were virtually because of silver traces induced to the chemical composition due to there were no specific ions in the composition in silicate glasses can produced such obtained strong ultraviolet spectra. According to the previous explanation, it was consider that the surplus UV absorption obtained in the irradiated glass could be related to the sharing of UV absorption from divalent traces [24].
An obvious change in color was detected in the synthesized silicate glass samples after the process of irradiation that related to the formation of small band at about 420 nm assigned to the presence of
surface plasmon resonance (SPR) phenomenon of silver ions as reported previously by different authors [25,26], suggested the formation of precipitated AgNPs within the silicate glass samples.
For the definition of the direct and indirect energy band gap of the samples before and after the laser irradiation, (αhν)2 and (αhν)1/2 were obtained as a function of photon energy (hν) as shown in Figs. 6 and 7, respectively. According to the intercept of the best fit of lines in x-axis, the values of direct and indirect energy band gaps had been calculated from these figures and recorded in Table 2.
It has been indicated that the values of direct energy band gap for the samples before laser irradiation decreases from 4.32 eV to 4.04 eV and after laser irradiation it decreases from 3.34 eV to 3.06 eV with increasing the concentration of silver in silicate glasses. Similarity, the values of indirect energy band gap for the samples before laser irradiation was also found to be decreased from 3.71 eV to 3.33 eV and
after laser irradiation it decreases from 2.92 eV to 2.57 eV with increasing the concentration of silver in silicate glasses.
The decreasing in energy band gap values may be related to the existence of structural defects, which increase the localized states width. This theory obtained the resulted change in the available number of final states and the generation of localized state in the band gap that arerelated to the composition disorder.

sections.heading: 3.4. High Resolution Transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM)
sections.text: High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) of selected glassy sample containing higher silver concentration (G5) before and being subjected to the mentioned laser beam shown in Fig. 8. HRTEM confirmed the formation of silver nanoparticles that participated within the silicate glass sample while their diffraction pattern confirms XRD data.
